I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to Papua New Guinea (PNG) for the Port Moresby Power Grid Development Project.1 
 
2.  The  proposed  project  will  reduce  fossil  fuel  consumption,  increase  access  to,  and 
improve network reliability of the Port Moresby power grid. The project will assist PNG Power 
Limited  (PPL)  in  expanding  renewable  energy  generation,  connecting  currently  unserved 
customers,  and  significantly  improving  the  quality  of  electricity  supply.  The  project  will 
(i) upgrade  and  rehabilitate  two  hydropower  plants  (Rouna  1  and  Sirinumu  toe-of-dam); 
(ii) extend the grid to approximately 3,000 additional households, including strengthening the 
distribution network; and (iii) construct a new substation (Kilakila) and upgrade the existing 
substations. Project preparatory technical assistancewas utilized in project preparation.2 
 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Port Moresby is the largest urban center in PNG, with a population of 318,000 (2011) 
and is expanding rapidly thanks to ongoing strong economic growth. Port Moresby has the 
largest stand-alone power grid in PNG, with 47% of the national installed generation capacity, 
48% of the national households connected to grid-based electricity, and a peak load of about 97 
megawatts (MW).3 Load demand for the Port Moresby grid has increased significantly and 
demand is expected to keep rising, fuelled by high economic growth related to continued growth 
in the gas and mining sector and associated industries. By 2018, peak demand is anticipated to 
increase by 30% (annual average of 6%). The Port Moresby grid is currently fed by diesel 
generation (41%) and the Rouna Hydropower Cascade (59%).  
 
4.  Renewable energy (hydropower) has historically supplied most of the power for the Port 
Moresby  grid.  In  1994–1995,  hydropower  from  the  Rouna  cascade  (installed  capacity  of 
60 MW)4 accounted for 76% of power generation for Port Moresby. By 2010–2011 however, due 
to  increasing  demand  and  deferred  rehabilitation  of  the  Rouna  cascade,  the  share  of 
hydropower  in  the  energy  mix  had  fallen  to  59%,  with  diesel  generation  filling  the  gap.5 
Maximizing  the  use  of  renewable  energy  (primarily  hydropower)  is  important  to  the  PNG 
economy, as it (i) reduces fossil fuel imports; (ii) lowers the cost of power generation and 
thereby eases the pressure on power tariffs, which in turn benefits the private sector and 
reduces household expenditure; and (iii) improves energy security. Utilization of renewable 
energy also reduces greenhouse gas emissions, which contribute to global warming. To meet 
projected medium- to long-term demand growth, additional hydropower for the Port Moresby 
grid is to be generated by the Naoro-Brown hydropower project (60 MW). The government is in 
the initial stages of assessing options for public–private partnership financing of the Naoro-
Brown hydropower project, supported by a technical assistance loan from the World Bank. 
However, since large hydropower plants require long planning and construction lead times, 
there  is  an  urgent  need  for  investments  in  the  Rouna  cascade  to  (i)  secure  immediate

2 
rehabilitation of the hydropower infrastructure, (ii) meet immediate demand, (iii) offset the need 
for further short-term investment in diesel generation, and (iv) reduce reliance on high-cost 
imported  fossil  fuels.  Refurbishing  the  existing  infrastructure  is  considered  the  least-cost 
option—the levelized cost of energy from a rehabilitated Rouna 1 hydropower plant is estimated 
at  $0.10–$0.16  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh)  compared  with  a  levelized  avoided  cost  of  diesel 
generation of $0.45/kWh.  
 
5.  Improving access to energy is a major developmental priority for PNG. In recognition of 
the low access rates across the country, the PNG Development Strategic Plan, 2010–2030 has 
established a national target of 70% access by 2030.6 Increasing access will involve extending 
existing grids in urban and peri-urban areas, establishing mini-grids to service isolated urban 
and rural population centers, and expanding individual power systems such as household solar 
systems and solar lanterns for isolated households and villages. Expansion options hinge on 
how power will be utilized and on least-cost delivery. Typically, peri-urban areas have a greater 
need for grid-connected power due to greater potential for economic activity, while demand from 
rural areas relates to low-usage activities such as lighting and communications. The proposed 
project focuses on extending the grid to currently unserved areas in urban and peri-urban areas 
of Port Moresby. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is also assisting access expansion to 
provincial urban and rural areas, but in separate interventions.7 The access rate in urban and 
peri-urban areas of Port Moresby is estimated at 69%. The project is targeting grid extension to 
an estimated 3,000 low-income households in these areas, which will increase the access rate 
to 74%.  
 
6.  Lack of access to reliable power is limiting economic growth and hindering private sector 
development.  A  sample  survey  of  75  households  conducted  under  technical  assistance 
associated with this project, found that 100% of them experienced frequent disruptions in power 
supply and extended blackouts. Of the sampled households, 35% were using power to also run 
small businesses. Improvement of power supply will enhance the quality of life and reduce 
poverty  by  encouraging  low-income  families  to  engage  in  small-scale  income  generation 
activities, e.g., sale of cooked and refrigerated items, and by improving street illumination to 
reduce  criminal  activity.  Thus,  investments  in  the  Port  Moresby  grid  transmission  and 
distribution infrastructure are essential to (i) step up hydropower system efficiencies and reduce 
the need for diesel power generation, (ii) reduce loss of revenue from high system losses, (iii) 
reduce costs to the private sector, and (iv) improve the quality of life of residential customers. 
 
7.  Power outages on the Port Moresby power grid are becoming more and more frequent. 
The average annual duration of power outages per customer (customer average interruption 
duration index) is 124 hours per annum. This is high compared with the Pacific-wide average of 
10 hours per annum.8 Power disruptions are due to overloaded substations, lack of generation 
capacity, and non-optimal grid configuration. Because of the unreliability of power supply, there 
is  considerable  self-generation  and  back-up  generation  capacity  in  urban  areas,  which  is 
maintained and operated at low efficiencies and high cost to businesses.

3 
8.  The Port Moresby power grid is owned and operated by PPL, a 100% state-owned 
enterprise. The government's ownership in PPL is maintained through the Independent Public 
Business  Corporation  (IPBC).  Sector  policy  formulation  is  managed  by  the  Department  of 
Petroleum and Energy and, specifically, by the Energy Division. PPL operates two main grids 
(Port Moresby and Ramu), which are not interconnected, and 26 smaller urban centers through 
19 separate power systems. Power tariffs in PNG are independently regulated by the Consumer 
and Competition Commission and allow full cost recovery for PPL. Electricity tariffs are currently 
K0.8147/kWh ($0.39/kWh) for residential customers with the first 30 kWh/month at a lifeline tariff 
of K0.4794/kWh ($0.23/kWh). Greater grid efficiencies and replacement of diesel generation 
with hydropower generation will ease pressure on power tariffs in the medium to long term.  
 
9.  The proposed project is in line with (i) ADB's country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for 
PNG,9 which prioritizes energy as an area of support, and (ii) the PNG Development Strategic 
  
Plan, 2010–2030 [footnote 6], which gives priority to the improvement of power supply. The 
 
government approved the electricity industry policy in 2011, which recognizes the (i) low level of 
electricity access, (ii) unreliability of electricity supply and subsequent economic impacts, (iii) 
high costs for the private sector arising from the supply gaps, and (iv) difficulties faced by PPL in 
raising capital for infrastructure investments. The proposed development of the PNG power 
sector, including the Port Moresby grid, is detailed in PPL's 15-year power development plan. 
The outputs of the project are included in PPL's 5-year business plan. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The  impact  will  be  more  economic  activities  undertaken  by  PPL's  residential  and 
business customers. The outcome will be better power supply for Port Moresby.  
 
C.  Outputs 
11.  The outputs of the project are as follows: 
(i)  Hydropower upgrade and rehabilitation. This consists of (a) upgrading the 
Rouna 1 hydropower plant (6 MW), and (b) rehabilitating and upgrading the 
Sirinumu toe-of-dam hydropower plant (1.6 MW). After upgrade and rehabilitation, 
the two plants will provide 13% of the renewable energy, or 3.6% of the total 
energy, for the Port Moresby grid.  
(ii)  Upgraded distribution grid. This entails (a) extending the grid to an estimated 
3,000  additional  households, 10  (b)  upgrading  the  existing  11-kilovolt  (kV) 
distribution  grid,11 and  (c)  implementing  a  loss  reduction  program.12 It  is 
estimated that the project will connect 5% more households in Port Moresby 
(generally from poorer areas) and boost the access rate from 69% to 74%.  
(iii)  Upgraded substation capacity. This consists of (a) constructing a new Kilakila 
substation, (b) a 6.1-kilometer (km) transmission line (66 kV), and (c) retrofits to 
existing substations. It is estimated that the project (distribution and substation 
upgrades) will reduce average outage duration for customers by 42% (by 80% 
within the central business district), contributing markedly to better power supply.

13.  The government has requested a loan of $51.7 million from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources (OCR). The OCR loan will have a 20-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, 
custom-tailored  repayment method,  an  annual  interest rate  determined  in  accordance  with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 
0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the draft guarantee and 
loan agreements. The repayment dates will be 1 June and 1 December. Based on this, the 
average loan maturity is 13.8 years, and the maturity premium payable to ADB is 0.10% per 
annum.  
 
14.  The  government  has  also  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
SDR9,787,000  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources—i.e.,  the  Asian  Development  Fund 
(ADF)—to help finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period 
of 5 years, an interest rate of 2.0% per annum, and such other terms and conditions as set forth 
in the draft loan agreements. The government will relend the proceeds of the OCR loan and the 
ADF loan to PPL under subsidiary loan agreements acceptable to ADB. The terms for relending 
the proceeds of the OCR and ADF loans will include the same interest rates and repayment 
periods that apply to the loans themselves. The financing charges during construction on the 
OCR and ADF loans will be capitalized.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  IPBC will be the executing agency and PPL will be the implementing agency. A PMU will 
be established within PPL for implementing the project. PPL will provide the following full-time 
PPL staff: (i) two project engineers, (ii) a land officer, (iii) an environment officer, (iv) a finance 
officer,  (v)  a  procurement  officer,  (vi)  a  surveyor,  (vii)  two  line  engineers,  and  (viii)  an 
administrative assistant. The project will finance additional consultants, equipment, and office 
furnishings to help the PMU implement the outputs. Consulting firms will be engaged using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 (considered justified 
due to the technical complexity of the power grid upgrades). Consultants may also be recruited 
through  individual  consultant  selection  (considered  justified  given  the  difficulties  in  finding 
consulting companies with the broad technical spread required, and a limited pool of consultants 
with required technical and country expertise). All consultants will be recruited in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The 
PMU will be responsible for contracting all consulting services, equipment, and civil works. A 
project steering committee will oversee implementation, monitor progress, and provide guidance 
to the executing agency. The committee will meet at least quarterly and will be chaired by the 
Department of National Planning and Monitoring. PMU will host the steering committee and act 
as the secretariat. 
 
17.  The project will be implemented over 4 years, with completion estimated by January 
2017. To expedite implementation, the government has requested and ADB has approved 
advance procurement action and retroactive financing for eligible expenditure up to a maximum 
of 18% of the ADF loan and 18% of the OCR loan, incurred before loan effectiveness, but not 
more  than  12  months  before  the  signing  of  the  loan  agreement.  ADB  has  informed  the 
government that approval of advance procurement action and retroactive financing does not 
commit ADB to finance the project. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 
3 and described in detail in the project administration manual.13

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
18.  The  proposed  substation  and  distribution  grid  upgrades,  and  the  upgrade  and 
rehabilitation of the hydropower plants have been assessed to be technically viable. Extensive 
modeling  has  been  completed  to  determine  the  optimum  technical  configuration,  including 
analysis of alternative substation locations, hydropower turbine size configurations, penstock 
arrangements,  and  distribution  configurations  to  maximize  system  efficiencies.  The  project 
design was based on extensive PNG experience to ensure that the proposed systems are 
suitable for local conditions, and the operation and maintenance requirements are compatible 
with  utility  capacity to ensure sustainable operation.  Alternative  designs  were  assessed  to 
ensure a least-lifecycle-cost design.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
19.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of the consolidated project is 17.9%, with a 
project  economic  net  present  value  of  $30.2  million.  This  compares  favorably  with  ADB’s 
economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. The access expansion program, in particular, has a 
high and robust EIRR of 21.9% that justifies the project despite the low financial viability of 
some project elements (Table 4).

7 
 
20.  The financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of the consolidated project is 10.2%, with a 
project financial net present value of $146.2 million. This compares favorably with the weighted 
average  cost  of  capital  of  2.0%  and  indicates  that  the  project  as  a  whole  is  financially 
sustainable.

21.  Both economic and financial viability indicators are robust, i.e., the EIRRs remain above 
12%, and the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) is above the weighted average cost of 
capital for all components. A sensitivity analysis was conducted to account for increases in 
economic and financial costs, as well as a reduction of economic and financial benefits. Both 
FIRR and EIRR are robust to cost increase and benefit reduction.14  
 
C.  Governance 
22.  Financial management. A financial management assessment was completed for PPL, 
including a review of the accounting and reporting system, internal and external auditing, fund 
disbursement, and information system.15 The assessment indicated that while PPL's financial 
management is generally satisfactory, improvements could be made in the areas of internal 
control relating specifically to account reconciliation procedures, prevention of re-statement of 
accounts at regular intervals, and integration of systems into the Oracle-based accounting 
system. PPL is now dealing with these issues, and they are not anticipated to impact PPL's 
management of the project. Design and supervision consultants will provide support.  
 
23.  Procurement capacity. A procurement capacity assessment was completed for PPL. It 
indicated that PPL has significant experience procuring goods and services and has sufficient 
procurement experience and human resources to manage procurement for the project, including 
the preparation of bidding documents, evaluation of technical proposals, and monitoring of 
contract performance. The assessment found some areas that require realignment to comply 
with ADB systems: (i) lack of specific technical specification or bill of quantities and price

(iv) lack of a complaints procedure. Based on this risk evaluation, the PMU will include an 
international procurement specialist who will train PPL staff in preparing tender documents and

specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are  described  in  the  project 
administration manual. PPL’s asset management procedures were assessed and considered 
sufficient to operate and maintain the assets under the project.  
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
24.  Social. The project aims to connect 3,000 households out of an estimated 17,800 non-
connected households in the poorer peri-urban villages of Port Moresby. Access to electricity 
will (i) reduce household chores such as collecting firewood, which is mainly done by women; 
(ii)  replace  kerosene  lighting  with  a  cheaper  form  of  energy,  thereby  freeing  household 
expenditure; (iii) improve children's education; and (iv) reduce indoor health and safety issues 
associated with burning firewood and kerosene. The project is also expected to provide more 
reliable power supply to broader residential areas, including poor areas in Port Moresby. Better 
power supply will enhance the quality of life of Port Moresby residents by (i) reducing now-
regular power outages for residents; (ii) encouraging low-income families to engage in small-
scale income generation activities such as selling cooked and refrigerated items, which is now 
not possible due to regular extended power outages; (iii) improving street illumination to reduce 
crimes; and (iv) improving the water supply to residents, which is disconnected during regular 
extended power outages.  
 
25.  Gender. The project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming, and a gender 
action  plan  has  been  prepared for  project  implementation  and monitoring.  Gender  actions 
include (i) prioritizing households headed by women for connection to the grid; (ii) undertaking 
training workshops in newly connected communities (at least 50% female participation) on 
electricity  safety,  operation  of  prepayment  meters,  energy  efficiency,  and  household  utility 
budgeting;  (iii)  conducting  training  workshops  in  five  communities  (at  least  50%  female 
participation) on using electricity for income generation; (iv) fostering women's participation in 
community consultations (at least 40%); (v) including at least one woman on the grievance 
redress  mechanism  committee;  (vi)  requiring  contractors  to  pay  equal  wages  to  men  and 
women for work of equal value, providing female workers with sanitation facilities, and including 
women in labor-based work (at least 20% women workers); (vii) ensuring that women’s wages 
are paid directly to them; (viii) conducting gender awareness training for contractors, the PMU, 
and PPL management; and (ix) including an international social and gender specialist to support 
the PMU.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
26.  Environment. The project overall has been classified as category B for environment 
following ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). An initial environmental examination has 
been prepared for each component. The main potential environmental impacts will arise from 
land clearing, earthworks, dust, noise, tree trimming, sourcing and transportation of materials, 
construction traffic, waste disposal and discharges, cleaning and refurbishment of hydropower 
plants,  and  minor  upgrade  of  an  access  road.  The  results  of  the  initial  environmental 
examinations will be integrated into the bidding documents for each component and if there are 
scope changes, an updated environmental examination and environmental management plan

9 
will be compiled by the PMU and approved by ADB. As part of the assessment, a climate 
change adaptation risk evaluation was conducted and considered in the infrastructure design.16 
 
27.  Involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples. The project has been classified as 
category B for involuntary resettlement and category C for indigenous peoples following ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement. The project does not involve physical displacement of people or 
structures,  but  requires  acquisition  of  about  5.47  hectares  of  customary  land  for  the  new 
substation and transmission line, affecting 198 families (744 individuals). A land acquisition and 
resettlement plan has been prepared for the new substation and transmission line site. A due 
diligence  report  has  been  prepared  for  existing  sites  (including  Rouna  1  hydropower  and 
Sirinumu toe-of-dam hydropower). PPL will update and finalize the resettlement plan and due 
diligence  report  prior  to  project  implementation.  PPL  will  coordinate  land  acquisition  and 
compensation activities with government and nongovernment agencies. Due diligence carried 
out under project preparatory technical assistance has confirmed that there will be no impact on 
distinct and vulnerable indigenous peoples. Consultation with affected persons has been carried 
out  during  project  preparation.  The  draft  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  plan  has  been 
disclosed on the ADB website.  All updated safeguard documents will be endorsed by the 
government, disclosed to affected persons and local stakeholders and posted on ADB website. 
The project will support capacity within PPL to manage safeguard aspects through international 
and national environment and social safeguard specialists, who will be working within the PMU. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
28.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 5 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.17 The risks have been assessed and the 
benefits are expected to outweigh the costs.

  IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
29.  The government, IPBC, and PPL have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. The government, 
IPBC, and PPL have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth 
in the loan agreement and project agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
30.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, I recommend that the Board 
approve 
(i)  the loan of $51.7 million to Papua New Guinea for the Port Moresby Power Grid 
Development Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility; for a term of 20 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such 
other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in 
the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR9,787,000 to Papua New Guinea for 
the  Port  Moresby  Power  Grid  Development  Project,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 2.0% per annum; for a term of 25 
years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as 
are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements presented to the Board.
